importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: Date of Ace Frehley's death, marking a significant event in the legacy of the band Kiss and in rock music history.
The release year of Kiss's hit song 'Beth,' which reached No. 7 on the Billboard Top 100, highlighting the band's commercial success and cultural impact.
Year Ace Frehley left Kiss, illustrating a pivotal moment in the band's evolution and internal dynamics.
Year of a notable collaboration between Kiss and Garth Brooks on the song 'Hard Luck Woman,' showcasing the band's influence beyond rock into country music.
Year Frehley left Kiss again, marking a key period of transition and reevaluation of the band's direction and lineup.
Year the original four members of Kiss were inducted into the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame, during which a dispute arose over their eligibility, highlighting ongoing internal tensions.
Date of a concert at Madison Square Garden billed as Kiss’s last performance, indicating a significant cultural moment in the band’s touring history.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The mid-to-late 1970s marked the peak of Kiss’s popularity and influence, particularly during the glam rock era when they became a cultural phenomenon with iconic stage personas and music.
The 1990s and early 2000s saw a revival of Kiss’s original style, especially after bands like Nirvana and Weezer expressed admiration, cementing the band's influence on modern rock aesthetics.

keyTakeAways: Ace Frehley, a founding member of Kiss, died at 74 in Morristown, New Jersey, following a fall, and was surrounded by family.
Frehley was known as 'Space Ace' and was central to Kiss’s theatrical stage presence, including pyrotechnics and glowing guitars.
Kiss was a major force in the glam rock movement, influencing hair metal bands like Mötley Crüe and Poison, and inspiring a generation of rock musicians.

The original lineup of Kiss (Frehley, Paul Stanley, Gene Simmons, and Peter Criss) was the first to be inducted into the Rock & Roll Hall of Fame in 2014, though tensions arose over the inclusion of older members.
Frehley left the band twice, first in 1982 and again in 2002, but rejoined in the mid-1990s for a successful revival of the original style.
Kiss sold its catalog, brand, and intellectual property to Swedish company Pophouse Entertainment Group in 2024 for over $300 million, reflecting the enduring commercial value of the band.
Frehley was a roadie for Jimi Hendrix at 18 and began playing guitar at age 13, demonstrating early musical influence and dedication.
The band’s iconic look and stage show inspired a fashion and marketing revolution, with the makeup becoming a global phenomenon.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Ace Frehley, the original lead guitarist and founding member of the glam rock band Kiss, has died at the age of 74 in Morristown, New Jersey, following a fall. A key figure in the band’s theatrical stage presence as 'Space Ace,' Frehley helped shape the iconic image and sound of Kiss, which became a major cultural force in the 1970s. The band’s influence on the hair metal and rock genres—such as Mötley Crüe, Poison, and Nirvana—demonstrates its lasting legacy. Frehley left the band twice, most notably in 1982 and again in 2002, but rejoined in the 1990s for a revival of the original style. Despite internal disputes, including a 2014 Hall of Fame controversy over lineup eligibility, the band's enduring popularity and commercial value were affirmed when it sold its catalog to Pophouse Entertainment Group for over $300 million in 2024. Frehley’s early experiences, including working as a roadie for Jimi Hendrix, and his deep musical roots, underscore his significance in rock history.
title: Ace Frehley, Kiss’ original lead guitarist and founding member, dies at 74
